text.content: In this article, let's create a Navbar and footer for our website. Unlike other components/parts of our website, both Navbar and footer persist on every page of our website.

rich_text.plain_text: In this article, let's create a Navbar and footer for our website. Unlike other components/parts of our website, both Navbar and footer persist on every page of our website.

text.content: Unlike the classical HTML/CSS webpages, where the whole page is reloaded whenever a new event is initiated, JavaScript Framework based webpages render only the parts which need to be changed. This is much more efficient and gives a much better user experience.

rich_text.plain_text: Unlike the classical HTML/CSS webpages, where the whole page is reloaded whenever a new event is initiated, JavaScript Framework based webpages render only the parts which need to be changed. This is much more efficient and gives a much better user experience.

text.content: Know a bit about TailwindCSS

rich_text.plain_text: Know a bit about TailwindCSS

text.content: Before we start using Tailwind for our styling needs, let's get to know how it is different from conventional CSS and why you should consider using it in your next project.

rich_text.plain_text: Before we start using Tailwind for our styling needs, let's get to know how it is different from conventional CSS and why you should consider using it in your next project.

text.content: What is it?

rich_text.plain_text: What is it?

text.content: , etc., Tailwind doesn't directly provide pre-built components such as Navbar, Footer, Hero Sections, etc. What it provides is a huge assortment of classes, each applying single or, at times, a few CSS properties. It's you putting short forms of all CSS properties as classes in your HTML element. Tailwind has classes for nearly every property that you will need for styling. It also provides an easy and intuitive way to extend its base classes to add your own.

rich_text.plain_text: , etc., Tailwind doesn't directly provide pre-built components such as Navbar, Footer, Hero Sections, etc. What it provides is a huge assortment of classes, each applying single or, at times, a few CSS properties. It's you putting short forms of all CSS properties as classes in your HTML element. Tailwind has classes for nearly every property that you will need for styling. It also provides an easy and intuitive way to extend its base classes to add your own.

text.content: My assessment

rich_text.plain_text: My assessment

text.content: At first look, it might look a bit messy with the huge-a*s number of classes like in the below picture.

rich_text.plain_text: At first look, it might look a bit messy with the huge-a*s number of classes like in the below picture.

text.content: Image from
tailwindcss.com

But as you start using it more, you'll realize that it's not intimidating as it looks. In fact! It's quite enjoyable. The classes are predefined, so it helps maintain consistency by limited choices. I have used both Plain CSS and SCSS. They tend to become quite ugly as your component size increases. Here you need not switch between the component and its style as the style is defined inline!!?

rich_text.plain_text: But as you start using it more, you'll realize that it's not intimidating as it looks. In fact! It's quite enjoyable. The classes are predefined, so it helps maintain consistency by limited choices. I have used both Plain CSS and SCSS. They tend to become quite ugly as your component size increases. text.content: Let us first add the toggling logic for the main menu.

rich_text.plain_text: Let us first add the toggling logic for the main menu.

text.content:
<script>
import { ref, onMounted } from "@nuxtjs/composition-api";
export default {
  components: {
    BrandLogo: () => import("Images/logo-symbol.svg")
  },
  setup() {
    const isVisible = ref(false);
    const toggleVisibility = () => {
      isVisible.value = !isVisible.value;
    };

    return {
      isVisible,
      navItems,
      toggleVisibility,
      socialItems
    };
  }
};
</script>

    const toggleVisibility = () => {
      isVisible.value = !isVisible.value;
    };

    return {
      isVisible,
      navItems,
      toggleVisibility,
      socialItems
    };
  }
};
</script>
